Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json/ returning 404 (with trailing forward slash)" (#9227) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

Nuget Service Index

### Worked before?

Yes

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

Nexus adds a trailing slash to the service index url and expects both https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json/ and https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json to return the same response.

This can be seen in the answer to a similar issue here: https://issues.sonatype.org/browse/NEXUS-25357

The URL with the trailing backslash is not working today and we're unable to connect.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Nexus logs:
2022-08-26 11:08:27,231+0000 DEBUG [qtp897030751-965] admin com.sonatype.nexus.repository.nuget.orient.internal.OrientNugetProxyFacet - Fetching: GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json/ HTTP/1.1
2022-08-26 11:08:27,232+0000 DEBUG [qtp897030751-965] admin org.sonatype.nexus.httpclient.outbound - https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json/ > GET /v3/index.json/ HTTP/1.1
2022-08-26 11:08:27,232+0000 DEBUG [qtp897030751-965] admin org.sonatype.nexus.internal.httpclient.SharedHttpClientConnectionManager - Connection request: [route: {s}->https://api.nuget.org:443][total available: 2; route allocated: 0 of 20; total allocated: 2 of 200]
2022-08-26 11:08:27,232+0000 DEBUG [qtp897030751-965] admin org.sonatype.nexus.internal.httpclient.SharedHttpClientConnectionManager - Connection leased: [id: 638][route: {s}->https://api.nuget.org:443][total available: 2; route allocated: 1 of 20; total allocated: 3 of 200]
2022-08-26 11:08:27,409+0000 DEBUG [qtp897030751-965] admin org.sonatype.nexus.httpclient.outbound - https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json/ < HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found @ 177.7 ms
2022-08-26 11:08:27,410+0000 DEBUG [qtp897030751-965] admin com.sonatype.nexus.repository.nuget.orient.internal.OrientNugetProxyFacet - Response: HttpResponseProxy{HTTP/1.1 404
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[A11y][ScreenReader]NVDA is not announcing the warning suggestion before the reading the line under the Paket CLI command." (#9172) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Original: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1555446

Repro Steps:
Hit https://www.nuget.org and press Enter key.
Navigate to "Sign in" control and press Enter key 
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and press Enter key
Search for a key term (say “json”) from search box.
Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and press Enter key
6. Navigate to "Paket CLI" control and press Enter key
Verify that the screen reader is announcing warning suggestion under the paket CLI command or not.

Note:
Similar issue can be observed with the Narrator also.

Actual Result:
NVDA is not announcing the warning suggestion before the reading the line under the Paket CLI command.

Expected result:
NVDA should be announce the warning suggestion before the reading the line under the Paket CLI command.

User Impact:
Screen Reader Users may be get confused whether the warning suggestion is not announced by the screen reader.

Notes:
There is likely an HTML element getting ignored. If not, we can maybe fix this by adding an invisible element with the content we want read out.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: 500 - Internal Server Error when accessing certain package pages" (#9226) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact I'm unable to use NuGet.org ### Describe the bug If in the package's README, a specific scenario exists, attempting to access the package's page results in a 500 error. This issue comes to light with the added support of internal links in READMEs. The 500 error occurs as a result of an unhandled NullReferenceException. This may be a result of a separate bug within Markdig (auto-links or auto-identifiers or a combination of the two). ### Repro Steps The following scenario must exist in the README for this issue to occur. Scenario: ``` # Heading [Link Text [Heading]](URL) ``` ### Expected Behavior The expected behavior of a README containing the scenario is two-fold: 1) Accessing the page for the package containing the README should not result in a 500 error. 2) The resulting HTML for the scenario should look like this: ```

Heading

Link Text [Heading]

``` ### Screenshots ![Screenshot 2022-09-07 151541](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25823466/189007584-1cd7dff7-935d-4abe-9617-c5e8a645a515.png) ### Additional Context and logs _No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[README]: Add section link support for READMEs" (#8833) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

Section links in READMEs don't work on NuGet.org.

For longer READMEs, it is pretty common to have a table of contents or similar with links to the various sections like in the "Examples" section for https://www.nuget.org/packages/Azure.Monitor.Query.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15097183/135529614-1b1820ae-3e31-4f37-ace7-74181e74b0bf.png)

### Repro Steps

1. Take the README Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/sdk/monitor/Azure.Monitor.Query/README.md
2. Add to your package and upload to NuGet.org
3. Notice that section links now just link back to the package details page (https://www.nuget.org/packages/Azure.Monitor.Query) rather than bringing you to the expected section.
4. 

### Expected Behavior

Clicking on a section link like `[logs query](#logs-query)` should bring you to the section of the README labeled "logs query". This is the standard behavior on GitHub.

### Screenshots

When I inspect element, this is what the section links look like on GitHub:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15097183/135530909-a2b6520c-c537-43bd-bf1e-c0301fd2d079.png)

This is what the section links look like on NuGet.org:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15097183/135530975-68f6f2c5-beaa-4bea-9fd1-28366eb82bfe.png)


### Additional Context and logs

This issue might be a result of README sections on NuGet.org not being linkable.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: Allow README URLs from Free Software Foundation Europe, REUSE" (#9200) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Uploading my nuget README.md gives:

> Some images are not displayed as they are not from [trusted domains](https://aka.ms/nuget-org-readme#allowed-domains-for-images-and-badges).

The URL in question is: https://api.reuse.software/info/github.com/dorssel/dotnet-aes-extra
(and the associated badge.

### The Elevator Pitch

Considering that REUSE is a widely used tool to ensure proper (open-source) licensing, and that nuget has a strong open-source incentive, I think such URLs should be whitelisted (either just api.reuse.software, or perhaps even *.reuse.software).

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Deleting an org doesn't warn that you cannot recreate one with the same name" (#7447) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
There have been cases where users have deleted an org only to find out that they cannot recreate it, similar to deleting user accounts. We should clarify this as part of the delete org workflow.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16904420/62957041-deb3ee00-bda8-11e9-8ada-485ce78716f2.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16904420/62958176-073ce780-bdab-11e9-9875-1caab4e097ed.png)

This is just suggested text. We should make it crisper when we pick this up.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Please fully qualify NuGet\Install-Package on the installer tab" (#9201) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

As a PowerShell Developer, I am excited to see a PowerShell install command on each package. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8278033/185921310-15f20721-1336-4260-9378-82fd2b81c34d.png)

But it always fails because `-Version` does not exist in my `Install-Package` command. Only `-RequiredVersion` exists.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8278033/185921499-5c820107-ed23-485f-aba7-c602fb488a3c.png)

After talking to others who figured this out, I now understand that there are two distinct `Install-Package` commands with incompatible parameters.

### Repro Steps

1. Open up a Windows PowerShell console, not a VS Developer console. 
2. Run `Install-Package Microsoft.Playwright -Version 1.25.0`
3. This uses `Install-Package` from Microsoft's `PackageManagement` module
4. Fail

### Expected Behavior

Whatever is provided on NuGet.org should work.

Considering the naming convention is problematic, please fully qualify the command on the website so that end-users have a hint that there are two commands from Microsoft with the same name that are different.

```
NuGet\Install-Package Microsoft.Playwright -Version 1.25.0
```

Alternatively, please rename your command to `Install-NuGetPackage` for better alignment and clarity.

The "Package Manager Console" is also confusing to people who aren't intimately familiar with Visual Studio. Perhaps add a PowerShell tab with the proper syntax right after the Cake tab.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8278033/185923725-e2141b12-98dc-4e35-929e-0ea4fb58807f.png)

In that tab would be
```
PackageManagement\Install-Package Microsoft.Playwright -RequiredVersion 1.25.0
```

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][ScreenReader]NVDA is announcing extra information when the user activates the shortcut key for the heading 'H'." (#9173) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Original: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1555443

Repro Steps:
Hit https://www.nuget.orgb/ and press Enter key.
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say “json”) from search box.
Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Info" and "Statistics" section present on right of the screen.
Verify that the screen reader is announcing correctly or not when the heading shortcut key is activated on the Newtonsoft.json heading.

Note: 
This issue repros with NVDA only.

Actual Result:
NVDA is announcing a lot of extra information when the user activates the shortcut key for the heading 'H'.

Expected result:
NVDA should be announce the heading of Newtonsoft.json heading and its level when the user activated the heading shortcut key.

User Impact:
Screen Reader Users may be get confused when the screen reader should announce the whole thing in one go when the user activated the heading shortcut key.

Notes:
I am unsure what NVDA considers to be the heading, but it is likely there is too much stuff under what NVDA considers the heading (especially considering that the issue does not repro on Narrator). Any fix we try here would need to be verified in Narrator so we can make sure we don't break that scenario.

1. Take the README Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/sdk/monitor/Azure.Monitor.Query/README.md
2. Add to your package and upload to NuGet.org
3. Notice that section links now just link back to the package details page (https://www.nuget.org/packages/Azure.Monitor.Query) rather than bringing you to the expected section.
4. 

### Expected Behavior

Clicking on a section link like `[logs query](#logs-query)` should bring you to the section of the README labeled "logs query". This is the standard behavior on GitHub.

### Screenshots

When I inspect element, this is what the section links look like on GitHub:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15097183/135530909-a2b6520c-c537-43bd-bf1e-c0301fd2d079.png)

This is what the section links look like on NuGet.org:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15097183/135530975-68f6f2c5-beaa-4bea-9fd1-28366eb82bfe.png)


### Additional Context and logs

This issue might be a result of README sections on NuGet.org not being linkable.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package quality warnings on NuGet.org upload page Spec" (#9225) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "[Bug]: Rename VS NuGet Options "Clear NuGet Cache(s)" button" (#12076) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

all

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

Before `PackageReference`, when `packages.config` was the only way to use Nuget, the global packages folder was very similar to a cache (except that nothing ever expired, or got cleaned automatically).

However, since the `PackageReference` feature came out, the global packages folder is where MSBuild, the compiler, and other build tools will read files from. Therefore, it is no longer private storage for NuGet's internal use. As a consequence, the NuGet team has progressively reduced calling the global packages folder a cache, even if many customers still call it the "NuGet cache".

The NuGet general options page in VS options, there's a button that still says "Clear Nuget Cache(s)".  This could be renamed to make it more obvious that clicking the button deletes not only the global packages folder, but other ones as well. Also, it might help slowly de-associate the global packages folder as being "the cache".

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Documentation:  NuGet API documentation does not describe possible exceptions" (#8380) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/visual-studio-extensibility/nuget-api-in-visual-studio.

XML doc comments for each interface member should describe which exceptions may be thrown and why via the [`<exception />`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/programming-guide/xmldoc/exception) tag.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: 5 minutes to install the nuget package with a lot of package files" (#12083) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

I'm creating an msbuild task which we deliver as a nuget package. Everything works fine so far, the task does what it should but a problem is the installation of the nuget package. It takes around 5 minutes to install the nuget package and there is not real log to identify the source of the lag.

During development I simply increase the version number to show a new package version. Afterwards I go to a demo project that contains the nuget package. I then simply update the nuget package in my demo project to the latest version, and this is what I get:

```
Restoring NuGet packages...
Running restore with 32 concurrent jobs.
Reading project file D:\GIT\IPIPE\Libraries\Managed\siemens.CUDA\siemens.CUDA.csproj.
The restore inputs for 'siemens.CUDA' have changed. Continuing restore.
Restoring packages for D:\GIT\IPIPE\Libraries\Managed\siemens.CUDA\siemens.CUDA.csproj...
Restoring packages for .NETCoreApp,Version=v6.0...
Resolving conflicts for net6.0...
Scanning packages for runtime.json files...
Restoring packages for net6.0/win-x64...
Resolving conflicts for net6.0/win-x64...
```

After around 5 minutes I get this output

```
Feeds used:
    https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.jsonC:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\
    D:\GIT\IPIPE\_Build\Release\Assemblies\ipipe.Cuda.Design
    Restored D:\GIT\IPIPE\Libraries\Managed\siemens.CUDA\siemens.CUDA.csproj (in 4,54 min).
NuGet package restore finished.
Time Elapsed: 00:04:32.6545900
```
Due to the transitivity of the project it takes more than 1 hour until my solution has restores (230 projects, but not all of them contains a relation to the package), but even if 10 projects contains a relation it takes around 50 minutes.

The problem is that I do not see who is wasting time. Is there anything I can do to get more logging?


### Repro Steps

For sure it has to do with my package and what I do, but there is no possibility to get some logs to identify the problem (?)

### Expected Behavior

In the end I expect a faster behavior but as said above I cannot get some logs to find out where it blocks. 

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Everything works fine so far, the task does what it should but a problem is the installation of the nuget package. It takes around 5 minutes to install the nuget package and there is not real log to identify the source of the lag. During development I simply increase the version number to show a new package version. Afterwards I go to a demo project that contains the nuget package. I then simply update the nuget package in my demo project to the latest version, and this is what I get: ``` Restoring NuGet packages... Running restore with 32 concurrent jobs. Reading project file D:\GIT\IPIPE\Libraries\Managed\siemens.CUDA\siemens.CUDA.csproj. The restore inputs for 'siemens.CUDA' have changed. Continuing restore. Restoring packages for D:\GIT\IPIPE\Libraries\Managed\siemens.CUDA\siemens.CUDA.csproj... Restoring packages for .NETCoreApp,Version=v6.0... Resolving conflicts for net6.0... Scanning packages for runtime.json files... Restoring packages for net6.0/win-x64... NuGet package restore finished. Time Elapsed: 00:04:32.6545900 ``` The problem is that I do not see who is wasting time. Is there anything I can do to get more logging?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Connection] Deprecating legacy cipher suites at www.nuget.org" (#63) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In order to provide a more secure and compliant environment for our customers, we are planning to deprecate legacy cipher suites and only support the following cipher suites at [www.nuget.org](http://www.nuget.org/):

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

Between 08/31/2022 07:00 PM UTC and 09/02/2022 07:00 PM UTC, we will take a test for this deprecation to understand the broken change for our customers. Based on our telemetry, we expect the impact to be minimal, but if you meet any connection issues at [www.nuget.org](http://www.nuget.org/) or have any questions, do reach out to us at [support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org) or by commenting on the discussion issue: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9216. We will be closely monitoring our communication channels to assess any unexpected impact.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability" (#62) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1, NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0). This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET Core 3.1, and NuGet clients (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0) where a nuget.org credential could be leaked. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/nuget/home/issues. (TBD) ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.0.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.11.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.9.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.7.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 4.9.4 version or earlier. ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET 6.0 application running on .NET 6.0.5 or earlier. - Any .NET 3.1 application running on .NET Core 3.1.25 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet.exe, NuGet package, or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET Core 3.1 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version 4.9.5, 5.7.2, 5.9.2, 5.11.2, 6.0.2, 6.2.1). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.11.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.11.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.11.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.9.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.9.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.9.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.7.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.7.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.7.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 5.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 4.9.4 or lower, you should download and install 4.9.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v4.9.5/nuget.exe. You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` If you're using .NET Core 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.6 or SDK 6.0.106 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.0) or SDK 6.0.301 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.2) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. If you're using .NET Core 3.1, you should download and install Runtime 3.1.26 or SDK 3.1.420 (for Visual Studio 2019 v16.9 or Visual Studio 2011 16.11 or Visual Studio 2022 17.0 or Visual Studio 2022 17.1) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/3.1 .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1 updates are also available from Microsoft Update. To access this either type "Check for updates" in your Windows search, or open Settings, choose Update & Security and then click Check for Updates. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 5 or .NET 6.0, please email details to [secure@microsoft.com](secure@microsoft.com). Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at [https://aka.ms/corebounty](https://aka.ms/corebounty). ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at [https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client). The [Announcements repo](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues) will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### External Links [CVE 2022-30184](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-30184) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 14, 2022): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2022-06-14_
